description: From Middle English nevere, navere, nævere, from Old English nǣfre (“never”), equivalent to ne +‎ ever.

entries.meaning: At no time; on no occasion; in no circumstance.
examples: "I never thought you were so fond of Mr. Phillips that you'd require two handkerchiefs to dry your tears just because he was going away," said Marilla.

entries.meaning: Not at any other time; not on any other occasion; not previously.
examples: There is no jewel, be it of never so rich a price, which I set before this jewel: I mean your love.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Negative particle (used to negate verbs in the simple past tense; also used absolutely).
examples: The police say I stole the car, but I never did it.
You said you were going to mow the lawn today. – I never!
